DOC.TEXT: A Thai Airways Boeing 747 made an unscheduled landing here after two of its three inertial navigation systems malfunctioned and the plane flew more than 600 miles off course, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The errant Flight 741, en route from Seattle to Tokyo, was spotted by the Anchorage International Airport air-traffic control center, said FAA spokesman Paul Steucke. He said a controller gave directions to the nearest FAA navigation aid, at St. Paul Island in the Bering Sea, about 800 miles southwest of Anchorage, so the captain of the jet could establish its location. After learning that the plane carrying 319 people lacked fuel to reach Tokyo, the controller provided directions to Anchorage, Steucke said. Problems with the jetliner's inertial navigation systems were discovered when FAA inspectors checked them after the plane reached Anchorage, he said. The navigation devices were replaced in Anchorage and the plane continued on to Seattle, where passengers transfered to a Tokyo-bound flight, officials said. In 1983, Korean Airlines Flight 007 was shot down by a Soviet warplane after it ranged more than 100 miles off course over the Siberian island of Sakhalin, killing all 269 people aboard. It was speculated at the time that a failure of the plane's navigation systems might have figured in the course error, but a federal jury ruled in August that the victims' families could collect damages for the flight crew's ``willful misconduct.''
